Inspired by the popular program Pizza Party, Pizza Py Party is a command line program for ordering pizza from Domino's. Here is a list of some of the major features of this program:

  • Runs on any major operating system supported by Python
  • Utilizes the new Domino's online order form
  • Can be used at locations that the old QuikOrder site doesn't allow, such as my hometown Peoria, IL
  • Can use batch files for ordering many pizzas
  • Supports the use of online coupons
  • Can read default settings from a configuration file
  • Unattended / background operation
  • Pizza Py Party is licensed under the GNU General Public License

Changes since 0.1:

  • Positional arguments are now handled so Pizza Py Party now has command-line syntax that is more similar to Pizza Party. Check the documentation for more details
  • Added more crust choices and edited topping choices to correspond to the changes in the Domino's website
  • Trimmed down the code by around 100 lines
  • Pizza Py Party is now licensed under GPL version 3

Download: http://bored.homelinux.net/projects/pizza-py-party/pizza-py-party-0.2.tar.gz

Documentation: http://bored.homelinux.net/projects/pizza-py-party/man/

Credits: Travis Nickles (ryoohki7 AT yahoo DOT com) - Author Cory Arcangel (cory AT post-data DOT org) and Michael Frumin (mfrumin AT eyebeam DOT org) for making Pizza Party.

Yo people. It looks like the Domino's site has changed just enough so that Pizza Py Party is now broken. I am actually messing around with developing the script but I don't know if a new version will come out of it. So far, it seems like only one portion of the script is broken and it should be easy to edit the old script to get it work again so expect a fix shortly. Pizza Py Party will still technically remain unsupported though. I would like to support this app again but I won't do so until I have a way to actually test ordering pizza from the Domino's site. I know there is a Domino's close to the dorm that I will be staying at, Hamilton Hall, so hopefully they deliver to that dorm so I can support this app again.

Edit: I should finally mention that I put Pizza Py Party on Launchpad. https://launchpad.net/pizza-py-party

Man, I just found out that saving a page in WordPress overwrites the .htaccess file with its default .htaccess file. Why the hell does it do that when editing a page? The .htaccess file shouldn't even be touched unless I am explicitly editing the permalink structure of the site. Because of this and other quirks that I have mentioned before, I will be getting rid of clean permalinks on my blog. Man, WordPress is now starting to get on my nerves.

Edit: After removing clean permalinks, WordPress has gotten noticeably snappier.

Just wanted to mention that this blog has been upgraded. It now uses WordPress 2.3.2 as opposed to before when 2.0.11 was being used. The blog seems a little snappier and I might actually take the time for enable url rewriting to allow for clean URLs. After all the time that I have used Django, I am tired of seeing URLs with query-strings in them on my blog.

Edit: It looks like clean permalinks will work fine for my current site. There were some initial conflicts with my Django apps not being accessible but those issues have been resolved now. Explicit rewrite conditions are put into place to allow the apps to be accessible.

2nd Edit: On second thought, WordPress seems to be more system intensive with the latest update especially regarding memory usage. My server can't really handle the load of rendering pages well anymore. The CPU peaks for a couple of seconds when rendering the index page and uses up around, sometimes over, 10 MB of memory. WordPress was always at the point where it worked well enough to use but the latest update has put it over the limit so I am not sure what I will do. If I had the money to buy a new server or to put this site on a web hosting server then I would do that. It would make things a lot easier.

Web sites that I helped create
This is a collection of web sites that I have created for recreation.
These projects are primarily desktop-oriented applications.

My Illinois State is a website that acts as a portal to the various online services that Illinois State University offers. The website is made using a custom framework mainly built using PHP and XSLT with SQL Server acting as the database. Unlike the previous portal software that the University was using, uPortal (aka iCampus), My Illinois State is better made to cater to all the various members of the Illinois State University community.

My involvement with the website was creating many different applications for the website. The biggest application that I helped create for My Illinois State was the event registration application for the Center for Learning, Teaching, and Technology department. A quick aside, my former colleague, Jamison Prianos, worked on the Java version of the application along with me; he was mainly responsible for creating the web service and the administration interface that the application used although I helped add new functions and maintain it. I was also involved with giving feedback on the framework as it was being made and patching the framework to add new functionality.

The Student Government Association Textbook Exchange System is a program that students can use to avoid the price gouging that college textbook stores inflict upon college students. Students can use the system to post textbooks that they want to sell to other students and other students can search the inventory of currently selling books in order to find textbooks required for classes at a discounted price.

My involvement with the website was creating the main infrastructure of the website using PHP for the backend, SQL Server 2008 for the database and XSLT for the template engine.

Hellfire Commentaries is a video commentary website focused around making commentaries for video games of various varieties and other media. The site owner and main commentator is Tom Stephens (aka NTom64). The site has a vast network of commentators that contribute to the website. The site also features a forum with a great community.

My involvement with the website involved upgrading the site from Drupal 6 to Drupal 7. The process included converting the data from custom SQL tables storing video playthrough data into Drupal nodes. This was achieved by writing a custom PHP script and making several node types using CCK. The process also involved converting a template to use Drupal 7 standards. Also, pages using embedded PHP code for database access were removed and replaced with Views pages. Modern Drupal practices were implemented by using a variety of modules as well as some custom module code.

A mobile version of the website was also created. Views were created to generate dynamic RSS feeds which are used for the HFC Boxee application. Custom module code was written to use web services in order to obtain video information from YouTube and Blip.tv. I was also responsible for converting themes from PSD files to CSS.
Wifi hotspot finder focused on locations near the Peoria area

PeoriaWifi is a website focused on collecting information about various public hotspots in the Peoria, Illinois area and giving a way to search for hotspots. This website was developed as a way to learn GeoDjango and class-based views in Django.

GeoDjango is used to do geospacial database lookups as well as plotting hotspots on a Google map. Google geocoding service is used to look up the coordinates for a certain point based on a search. Memcached is used to cache the results from geocoding. The source code for the website can be found at https://github.com/Ryochan7/peoriawifi

Justice For All Revolution aims to be a social support platform for empowering people. Justice For All Revolution is powered by Drupal and I was a part of migrating the website from WordPress to Drupal along with my friend Sean Tilley. My involvement with the development of the web site was making custom content types using CCK, assisting in the creation of pages using Views, making layout and cosmetic modification to the website using CSS, along with developing custom modules using PHP and SQL.

I was also responsible for implementing the subscription system needed so that private chatrooms would only be available to subscribers. This required debugging and making patches for the lm_paypal module.
Generates unlock code file for StepMania unlock system

This is a graphical program for generating unlock codes for the StepMania dance simulation game. This allows for locking of songs in an arcade style system. This program was originally written in Python but a Java version was also made. The primary version of this program used GTK for the GUI but a version using Qt for the interface was also made. The Python releases are the only ones to have a supported public release.
YouTube video downloader and transcoder for the GP2X

YouTubed-2x is a program for downloading flash videos from various services (such as YouTube) and transcoding them to video files compatible with the GP2X handheld gaming console. The application is written in Python and it uses GTK for the graphical user interface. The application supported a maximum of 24 video sites during its development.

The following are a couple of archives of the project. This application has not be supported for a while so it is very likely that no parsers work anymore. There is an included test script in case you are curious.

Linux Archive: 2011.03.26
Windows Archive: 2010.01.22

This website was developed as a news and event coordination site for a small gaming organization at Illinois State University. The website would be used by the administrators of the website to post pages and news stories about the organization. Members of the website would be allowed to post information about local gaming events on the community calendar and also mark themselves as attending events. Event information could be accessed on the website as well as using a calendar application. Gallery functionality was added to allow the administrators of the organization to post pictures taken at local gaming events.

The website was written in PHP utilizing a small framework that I had established. The source code for the website can be found at https://github.com/Ryochan7/UGA-Proposal-Website

This is my main website. It is written in Django and functions as a blog and a place to post information about my software projects. Some of the early content on this blog was imported from my old WordPress blog using an XML parsing Python script. The source code for the website can be found at https://github.com/Ryochan7/asylum
